newsitem.title: THAILAND: Foreign sales drive Thai stocks to fresh low.
newsitem.headline: Foreign sales drive Thai stocks to fresh low.

text.p: Thailand's battered stock market took another beating on Thursday as foreign selling of bank shares pushed the key index down to its lowest closing level since January 1991.
Although the index recovered slightly from the day's lows, it still ended down two percent, or 12.51 points, at 614.06.
The market has now lost 7.1 percent of its value in consecutive falls over the last four trading days.

"I've been told foreigners have been selling the banks and it has got some retail players panicky, while those foreign investors who might want to get in are sidelined," said a trader at Union Securities.
Analysts had feared bank shares would become a target for selling as some major bank stocks have recently outperformed the market.
There were a number of factors weighing on the market, traders said, and no fresh positive news to provide support.

They blamed poor sentiment on a combination of lower economic growth prospects, a disappointing corporate earnings outlook, sluggish export growth, liquidity concerns, a property slump and loan portfolio quality.
Several private analysts say the Thai economy will grow by only about five percent this year, its lowest level for a decade, and most current indicators suggest it is unlikely to rebound soon.
Concerns over weaker growth are translating into lower corporate growth prospects, prompted investors to unload bank, telecommunication and energy stocks during the day, traders said.
